entry.title: Introduction to React - Exercises: 1.2 - 1.5
entry.content:
8:15 AM: Focus Block

Complete Exercises 1.2 Introduction to React from Full Stack Open 2019

8:33 AM: Problem - Failed to compile

Problem

index.js, has failed to compile.

Insight:

Errors that I’m receiving are related to no-undef, the function not being defined.

9:00 AM: Completed exercise 1.2

9:01 AM: Code - Exercise 1.2

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';

const App = () => {
    const course = 'Half Stack application development'
    const part1 = 'Fundamentals of React'
    const exercises1 = 10
    const part2 = 'Using props to pass data'
    const exercises2 = 7
    const part3 = 'State of a component'
    const exercises3 = 14

    return (
      <div>
        <Header course = {course} />
        <Content part1 = {part1} exercises1 = {exercises1} />
        <Content part2 = {part2} exercises2 = {exercises2} />
        <Content part3 = {part3} exercises3 = {exercises3} />
        <p>Number of exercises {exercises1 + exercises2 + exercises3}</p>
      </div>
    )
}


const Header = (props) => {
  return <h1>{props.course}</h1>
}

const Part = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <p> {props.part1} {props.exercises1} </p>
      <p> {props.part2} {props.exercises2} </p>
      <p> {props.part3} {props.exercises3} </p>
    </div>
  )
}

const Content = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <Part part1 = {props.part1} exercises1 = {props.exercises1} />
      <Part part2 = {props.part2} exercises2 = {props.exercises2} />
      <Part part3 = {props.part3} exercises3 = {props.exercises3} />
    </div>
  )
}

const Total = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <p> {props.exercises1 + props.exercises2 + props.exercises3}</p>
    </div>

  )
}



ReactDOM.render(<App />, document.getElementById('root'));

10:20 AM: Reflection

The exercises have focused on syntax and using props with components. Before I start reading a new section, I’m going to review the exercises first to identify questions and areas to focus on while reading.

I’m going to dedicate time to read over the React documentation on props.

10:54 AM: Focus Block

Exercise 1.3

Let’s move forward to using objects in our application. Modify the variable definitions of the App component as follows and also refactor the application so that it still works:

const App = () => {
  const course = 'Half Stack application development'
  const part1 = {
    name: 'Fundamentals of React',
    exercises: 10
  }
  const part2 = {
    name: 'Using props to pass data',
    exercises: 7
  }
  const part3 = {
    name: 'State of a component',
    exercises: 14
  }

  return (
    <div>
      ...
    </div>
  )
}

11:02 AM: Emacs

  • Create keybindings for commenting and uncommenting a region.
  • Create a keybinding that allows for narrowing to definition, selected region etc

11:10 AM: Code - Exercise 1.3

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';

const App = () => {
  const course = 'Half Stack application development'
  const part1 = {
    name : 'Fundamentals of React',
    exercises: 10
  }
  const part2 = {
    name: 'Using props to pass data',
    exercises:  7
  }
  const part3 = {
    name: 'State of a component',
    exercises: 14
  }
    return (
      <div>
        <Header course = {course} />
        <Content part1 = {part1.name} exercises1 = {part1.exercises} />
        <Content part2 = {part2.name} exercises2 = {part2.exercises} />
        <Content part3 = {part3.name} exercises3 = {part3.exercises} />
      </div>
    )
}


const Header = (props) => {
  return <h1>{props.course}</h1>
}

const Part = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <p> {props.part1} {props.exercises1} </p>
      <p> {props.part2} {props.exercises2} </p>
      <p> {props.part3} {props.exercises3} </p>
    </div>
  )
}

const Content = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <Part part1 = {props.part1} exercises1 = {props.exercises1} />
      <Part part2 = {props.part2} exercises2 = {props.exercises2} />
      <Part part3 = {props.part3} exercises3 = {props.exercises3} />
    </div>
  )
}

const Total = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <p> {props.exercises1 + props.exercises2 + props.exercises3}</p>
    </div>

  )
}


ReactDOM.render(<App />, document.getElementById('root'));

11:14 AM: Reflection

Modified variable definitions of of App component to be objects instead, refactored accordingly.

11:19 AM: Exercise 1.4

And then place the objects into an array. Modify the variable definitions of App into the following form and modify the other parts of the application accordingly:

const App = () => {
  const course = 'Half Stack application development'
  const parts = [
    {
      name: 'Fundamentals of React',
      exercises: 10
    },
    {
      name: 'Using props to pass data',
      exercises: 7
    },
    {
      name: 'State of a component',
      exercises: 14
    }
  ]

  return (
    <div>
      ...
    </div>
  )
}

NB at this point you can assume that there are always three items, so there is no need to go through the arrays using loops. We will come back to the topic of rendering components based on items in arrays with a more thorough exploration in the next part of the course.

However, do not pass different objects as separate props from the App component to the components Content and Total. Instead, pass them directly as an array:

const App = () => {
  // const definitions

  return (
    <div>
      <Header course={...} />
      <Content parts={parts} />
      <Total parts={parts} />
    </div>
  )
}

11:28 AM: Objects and Arrays

The syntax for an object and an array in Javascript are similar to each other causing mistakes in syntax, especially when going from a Object -> Array.

Remember that in the array there is no need for a const, and that the brackets indicate the beginning and end of an element. Other oddities are the usage of the “,” and “[ ]“.

const parts = [
    {
      name : 'Fundamentals of React',
      exercises: 10
    },
    {
      name: 'Using props to pass data',
      exercises:  7
    },
    {
      name: 'State of a component',
      exercises: 14
    }
  ]

11:34 AM: Emacs

  • Create keybinding for scratch buffer
  • Set sane defaults for programming modes

11:47 PM: Exercise 1.5

Let’s take the changes one step further. Change the course and its parts into a single Javascript object. Fix everything that breaks.

const App = () => {
  const course = {
    name: 'Half Stack application development',
    parts: [
      {
        name: 'Fundamentals of React',
        exercises: 10
      },
      {
        name: 'Using props to pass data',
        exercises: 7
      },
      {
        name: 'State of a component',
        exercises: 14
      }
    ]
  }

  return (
    <div>
      ...
    </div>
  )
}

12:10 PM: Code - 1.4 and 1.5

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';

const App = () => {
  const course = {
    name: 'Half Stack application development',
    parts: [
    {
      name : 'Fundamentals of React:',
      exercises: 10
    },
    {
      name: 'Using props to pass data:',
      exercises:  7
    },
    {
      name: 'State of a component:',
      exercises: 14
    }
  ]
}
  return (
    <div>
      <Header course = {course.name} />
      <Content parts = {course.parts} />
      <Total parts = {course.parts} />
    </div>
  )
}

const Header = (props) => {
  return <h1>{props.course}</h1>
}

const Part = (props) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <p> {props.part.name} {props.part.exercises} </p>
    </div>
  )
}

const Content = ({parts}) => {
  return (
    <div>
      <Part part = {parts[0]} />
      <Part part = {parts[1]} />
      <Part part = {parts[2]} />
    </div>
  )
}

const Total = ({parts}) => {
  let total = parts[0].exercises + parts[1].exercises + parts[2].exercises;
  return (
    <div>
      <p> Number of exercises: {total} </p>
    </div>

  )
}

ReactDOM.render(<App />, document.getElementById('root'));

12:17 PM: Recovery Block

entry.title: Introduction to React - Exercise 1.1
entry.content:
Problem: Creating the Total component

Problem:

For exercise 1.1 from Full Stack Open, I had to refactor code from the App component to three separate components.

I was able to create the components for Header and Content, I experienced difficulty with the Total component.

Insight:

Received the following error:

Warning: Received NaN for the `children` attribute. If this is expected, cast the value to a string.

I believe this is related to the exercises variables being out of scope, or problems with reading a string and an integer.

Tomorrow:

I’m going to read over this section tomorrow and break down the problem further.

Code: Exercise 1.1

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';

const App = () => {
    const course = 'Half Stack application development'
    const part1 = 'Fundamentals of React'
    const exercises1 = 10
    const part2 = 'Using props to pass data'
    const exercises2 = 7
    const part3 = 'State of a component'
    const exercises3 = 14

    return (
      <div>
        <Header course = {course} />
        <Content part1 = {part1} exercises1 = {exercises1}/>
        <Content part2 = {part2} exercises2 = {exercises2}/>
        <Content part3 = {part3} exercises3 = {exercises3}/>
        <p>Number of exercises {exercises1 + exercises2 + exercises3}</p>
      </div>
    )
}

const Header = (props) => {
  return <h1>{props.course}</h1>
}

const Content = (props) => {
  return (
    <p>
    {props.part1} {props.exercises1}
    {props.part2} {props.exercises2}
    {props.part3} {props.exercises3}
    </p>
  )
}

ReactDOM.render(<App />, document.getElementById('root'));

entry.title: Chunking
entry.content:
Analogy

Chunking is like working through a jigsaw puzzle. You start with separate pieces, as you work on the puzzle, you create small clusters of pieces or chunks, which contain more meaning and further help you complete the puzzle.

Diagram/Example

Plain-English

Chunking is the process that allows us to connect smaller pieces of information into bigger chunks to help us remember for later.

Technical

Chunking is a process by which individual pieces of an information set are broken down and then grouped together. A chunk is a collection of basic familiar units that have been grouped together and stored in a person’s memory. These chunks are able to be retrieved more easily due to their coherent familiarity.

Importance

  • Short-term memory is where our brain briefly (20-30 seconds) stores new information, before either forgetting it or committing it to the long-term memory.

  • Long-term memory, amounts to approximately 7 (+/- 2) slots, newer research suggests that this number is closer to 4 slots.

As we are learning something new, our working memory gets overwhelmed by all the new information and is unable to hold it all in. As a result, we struggle to comprehend.

As information gets chunked, the same amount of information combined into one chunk occupies only 1 slot in our working and short-term memories, allowing for more information to be held.

entry.title: Learning strategies
entry.content:
In my previous post I discuss my intention of completing the “Deep Dive Into Modern Web Development” course with the purpose of starting a progressive journey on becoming a software developer. The primary focus of this post is providing a list of resources and learning strategies that are going to be used.

Resources

Over the years in my experience as being both a teacher and a student I have come across different resources that are related to the field of learning. The learning strategies that I’m adopting have been informed by the following sources:

  • A Mind For Numbers: How to Excel at Math and Science
  • Make It Stick: The Science of Successful Learning
  • Peak: Secrets from the New Science of Expertise
  • Pragmatic Thinking and Learning: Refactor Your Wetware
  • Articles from Better Explained

This is not an exhaustive list by any measure, there are plenty of other discussions about the topic, doing a search on Google yielded over 8 billion possible results.

The list here represents resources that I turn to when I need a refresher and have found works best for me.

The sources above were chosen for the specific strategies, findings, and thoughts that were presented about learning.

Strategies

What follows is a list of learning strategies and concepts that were presented in the books and articles listed above.

  • Chunking
  • Generation
  • Elaboration
  • Retrieval
  • Reflection
  • Interleaving
  • Calibration
  • Spacing
  • Deliberate Practice
  • ADEPT Method

In posts to come I will go deeper into each learning strategy and how I’m implementing them into an overall learning plan.

This post will be updated periodically with additional resources and strategies.

entry.title: Deep Dive Into Modern Web Development
entry.content:
As part of my learning journey to become a software developer, today I’m starting the course “Deep Dive into Modern Web Development”. The course is provided by the University of Helsinki as part of their Open University.

This course serves as an introduction to modern web application development with JavaScript. The main focus is on building single page applications with ReactJS that use REST APIs built with Node.js. The course also contains a section on GraphQL, a modern alternative to REST APIs.

The course covers testing, configuration and environment management, and the use of MongoDB for storing the application’s data.

As I work through this course, I will be documenting my progress by creating blog posts and videos that summarize what I’ve learned.

In the blog posts that follow I will go over the learning strategies that I’ll be incorporating and a deeper look into my learning plan and tools.

The “Deep Dive into Modern Web Development” course consists of 9 separate parts and 4-5 subparts.

  • Part 0: Fundamentals of Web Apps
    • a: General Info
    • b: Fundamentals of Web apps
  • Part 1: Introduction to React
    • a: Introduction to React
    • b: Javascript
    • c: Component state, event handlers
    • d: A more complex state, debugging React apps
  • Part 2: Communication with server
    • a: Rendering a collection, modules
    • b: Forms
    • c: Getting data from server
    • d: Altering data in server
    • e: Adding styles to React app
  • Part 3: Programming a server with NodeJS and Express
    • a: Node.js and Express
    • b: Deploying app to internet
    • c: Saving data to MongoDB
    • d: Validation and ESLint
  • Part 4: Testing Express servers, user administration
    • a: Structure of backend application, introduction to testing
    • b: Testing the backend
    • c: User administration
    • d: Token authentication
  • Part 5: Testing React apps, custom hooks
    • a: Login in frontend
    • b: props.children and proptypes
    • c: Testing React apps
    • d: Custom hooks
  • Part 6: Statement management with Redux
    • a: Flux-architecture and Redux
    • b: Many reducers, connect
    • c: Communicating with server in redux application
  • Part 7: React router, styling app with CSS and webpack
    • a: React router
    • b: More about styles
    • c: Webpack
    • d: Class components, E2E-testing
    • e: Miscellaneous
    • f: Exercises: extending the bloglist
  • Part 8: GraphQL
    • a: GraphQL-server
    • b: React and GraphQL
    • c: Database and user administration
    • d: Login and updating the cache
    • e: Fragments and subscriptions

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Over the years after many conversations with friends about niche topics, staying up late at night pondering life on the verge of an existential crisis, we have arrived here a blog in 2019? Bueno, mejor que nada This post is titled Hello World, it symbolizes the first step we take to attempt to communicate with someone or something else while being simultaneously born into a new digital world of our creation.

I want you to step into my world and Ill take you with me on this journey of becoming a software developer. The process of becoming a software developer is like attaining a new ability, to be able to see the world through a computational lens, the opportunity to creatively solve problems and to contribute, create and share knowledge with others.

This blog, this world thats being created will serve as a repository about what Im currently learning. I intend to share what Ive learned with others by creating content thats accessible to a wider audience. As someone who in the past has been deeply involved with community-building as a former community organizer, teacher, and mentor, I seek to bridge technology and social justice. I expect this journey to be filled with moments of joy, tears, and frustration Palante!
